question: Question_07
statement:
Consider the symmetric matrix

$A = \begin{bmatrix}
-2 &1 &0 \\ 
1 &-2 &1 \\ 
0& 1 &-2 
\end{bmatrix}$

Compute the matrix norms $\left \| A \right \|_{\infty}$ and
$\left \| A \right \|_{2 }$
sols:
The infinity norm of a matrix is the infinity norm of the vector whose
entries are the 1-norm of each row, so it will be

\[\displaystyle \left \| A \right \|_{\infty} = \max\{2+1+0, 1+2+1, 0+1+2\} = 4.\]

The 2-norm of a matrix is the largest of the absolute values of the
eigenvalues. So we need to calculate the eigenvalues of \emph{A} as the
roots of the characteristic polynomial

\begin{align*}
\det(A-\lambda I) &= \det\begin{vmatrix}
-2-\lambda & 1 & 0 \\
1 & -2-\lambda & 1 \\
0 & 1 & -2-\lambda \end{vmatrix} \\
&= (-2-\lambda) \det\begin{vmatrix}
-2-\lambda & 1 \\
1 & -2-\lambda \end{vmatrix} - (1)\det\begin{vmatrix}
1 & 0 \\
1 & -2-\lambda \end{vmatrix} \\
&= (-2-\lambda)((-2-\lambda)(-2-\lambda)-1)-(-2-\lambda) \\
&= (-2-\lambda)(\lambda^2+4\lambda+2)
\end{align*}

Hence, the eigenvalues of \emph{A} are $\displaystyle \lambda_1 = 2$ and
$\lambda_{2,3} = \frac{-4\pm\sqrt{16-8}}2 = -2\pm\sqrt 2$. The 2-norm of
\emph{A} is the largest of the absolute values of these and therefore
$\left \| A \right \|_{2 }$ = $2+\sqrt{2}$.
hints:
The infinity norm of a matrix is simply the maximum absolute row sum of
the matrix, that is, the largest 1-norm of its rows.

The 2-norm for a symmetric matrix is the largest absolute value of the
eigenvalues.
